Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Engineering Student Mental Wellness During the COVID-19 Pandemic

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration: As a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, some students will fall ill, potentially critically, while others will face the prospect of sick family members, and even deaths in the family. These experiences are likely to expose students to stress, uncertainty, and fear that may affect their mental health and academic performance for years to come. This study’s contribution will be significant because by studying the effects of the pandemic and academy’s response to it on engineering students, engineering departments will be able to create tailored approaches to help students recover and stay on track for graduation in the aftermath of this pandemic. The outcomes of this project will include: 1) characterizations of the impact the COVID-19 pandemic has on mental wellness and stress levels of various engineering student populations; 2) characterizations of coping strategies being used by students during the pandemic; 3) student reactions, positive and negative, to how their home institution handled the COVID-19 pandemic and any related changes in course delivery and university operations.<br/> <br/>The goal of this project is to study the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic and the academy’s response to it on mental health and baseline stress levels in engineering students from all backgrounds. The specific research aims are: 1) to determine how the conditions imposed by COVID-19 are affecting student baseline stress levels and mental wellness, and 2) to characterize student beliefs surrounding how well their institution has handled the COVID-19 outbreak, student coping strategies, and what students wish their institutions had done differently. Both aims will be accomplished through a nationwide survey targeting engineering students. Mental health and stress level will be measured with a compilation of validated instruments. The second aim will be accomplished through qualitative analysis of responses to a number of open-ended questions about student opinions and beliefs. This study is significant because it will be the first effort to assess the effects of pandemics and other large-scale emergencies on engineering students’ mental health and well-being, and will help inform how universities support returning students and handle such crises in the future.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In Spring 2020, the arrival of the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States led to widespread disruption in higher education and drastic changes for college students. This project, RAPID: Engineering Student Mental Wellness During the COVID-19 Pandemic, was developed to study the effects of these disruptions on the mental health of engineering students in the United States, to determine effective coping strategies used by students during these times, and to study the perceived effectiveness of universities? responses to the COVID-19 pandemic.

 

After conducting a nationwide survey of two- and four-year engineering students, we determined that the COVID-19 pandemic led to drastic increases in rates of depression among students, at least in the early phases of the pandemic. Led by this indicator, roughly 70% percent of respondents at both two- and four-year institutions screened positive for at least one potentially diagnosable mental health disorder, up from the roughly 50% seen in pre-COVID studies. Surprisingly, other measures of mental health, including anxiety disorders and major psychological distress, remained unchanged. Additionally, 36% of respondents reported that COVID-19 worsened their food security situation, 37% reported that COVID-19 worsened their housing security situation, and 39% reported that COVID-19 worsened their ability to access instruction or instructional materials.

 

The experiences of COVID-19 reshaped variance of mental health conditions across different demographic groups. Pre-COVID, members of marginalized populations in engineering including women and Hispanic/Latinx students were significantly more likely than men and white students to screen positive for conditions like major depressive disorder, PTSD, and certain anxiety disorders. These differences disappeared in our analysis of post-COVID data. Additionally, some marginalized populations like respondents identifying as Asian statistically fared better than White students on several mental health screens post-COVID. Some of this may be due to how well each of these groups fared in meeting basic needs due to the pandemic: women were only 68% as likely as men to have their housing situation negatively impacted due to COVID-19, and respondents identifying as Hispanic/Latinx were less than half as likely (47%) to have their food security negatively impacted because of COVID-19. Perhaps surprisingly, private school students had significantly higher odds of screening positive for major depressive disorder than their peers at public school (1.7 times). These respondents also are 2.7 times more likely to report negative impacts to food and housing security because of COVID-19.

 

Our analysis identified mindfulness and yoga-19 as potentially helpful coping strategies. While respondents who reported using these strategies did not fare better on any mental health screen, they scored significantly better on 20 individual mental health screening questions including questions relating to self-harm (?how often have you been bothered by thoughts that you would be better off dead or of hurting yourself in some way??), eating disorders, and severity of anxiety attacks.

 

Finally, from qualitative analysis, we determined a number of areas where students reported that universities and engineering faculty and administrators fell short in their handling of the COVID pandemic, and where they could potentially improve in similar emergencies in the future. Students reported that due to COVID and the ensuing switch to online teaching, many instructors assigned more work than they would in a face-to-face class, showed a lack of empathy for student difficulties?including technical difficulties accessing instruction?and created a number of course structure problems for students, from not adhering to specified exam times creating inter-class conflicts to relying on third-party YouTube videos as the sole source of lecture and instruction. Students also faulted academic administrators for many of these same problems, reporting a desire for more coordination at a college and department-wide level (i.e., not leaving organizational and grading decisions up to each individual instructor), more communication with professors on how long and frequently

exams should be given, better substitutions for labs, better and more communication with students and staff overall, and providing more help for instructors to transition to online learning. Students also identified issues with counseling and disability resource centers, reporting a desire for more services to be made available during emergencies like COVID, different services to respond to pandemic conditions specifically, and, for those already engaged with counseling or the disability service center on campus, a better continuity of services when instruction transitions to remote learning.

 

The data and analysis produced by this research has already led to several publications, workshops, and invited talks targeting engineering faculty and other stakeholders in engineering. The insights produced by this research will allow universities to better target support to student populations most affected by the pandemic, and will allow universities and engineering educators to better prepare for future COVID-style emergencies.

 

Publications, presentations, and research briefs from this project are listed below and/or available at www.sociologyofengineering.org.
